'''Xenotransplantation''' (''xenos-'' from the [[Greek language|Greek]] meaning "foreign" or strange<ref name=Dooldeniya2003>{{cite journal |last1=Dooldeniya |first1=M D  |last2=Warrens |first2=AN |title=Xenotransplantation: where are we today? |journal=Journal of the Royal Society of Medicine  |volume=96  |issue=3  |pages=111–117  |pmc=539416  |year=2003  |pmid=12612110  |doi=10.1177/014107680309600303  }}</ref><ref>{{cite journal |last1=Mitchell |first1=C Ben |title=Xenotransplanation and Transgenics: The Need to Discuss Limits |url=https://cbhd.org/content/xenotransplanation-and-transgenics-need-discuss-limits |website=Cbhd |access-date=19 November 2018 |date=2000-05-10 |archive-date=2018-11-19 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20181119051557/https://cbhd.org/content/xenotransplanation-and-transgenics-need-discuss-limits |url-status=dead }}</ref>), or '''heterologous transplant''', is the [[Organ transplant|transplantation]] of living [[cell (biology)|cell]]s, [[biological tissue|tissue]]s or [[organ (anatomy)|organ]]s from one [[species]] to another.<ref name=who>[https://web.archive.org/web/20050113212657/http://www.who.int/transplantation/xeno/en/ Xenotransplantation]. Definition by the World Health Organization</ref> Such cells, tissues or organs are called '''xenografts''' or '''xenotransplants'''. It is contrasted with [[allotransplantation]] (from other individual of same species), [[Syngenic|syngeneic]] transplantation or isotransplantation (grafts transplanted between two genetically identical individuals of the same species) and [[autotransplantation]] (from one part of the body to another in the same person).{{citation needed|date=April 2022}} Xenotransplantation is an artificial method of creating an animal-[[human chimera]], that is, a human with a subset of animal cells. In contrast, an individual where each cell contains genetic material from a human and an animal is called a [[human–animal hybrid]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://embryo.asu.edu/pages/hybrids-and-chimeras-consultation-ethical-and-social-implications-creating-humananimal-embryos|title="Hybrids and Chimeras: A Consultation on the Ethical and Social Implications of Creating Human/Animal Embryos in Research" (2007), by the HFEA|website=The Embryo Project at Arizona State University|author=Sarah Taddeo, Jason S. Robert|date=2014-11-04}}</ref>

[[Patient derived xenograft]]s are created by xenotransplantation of human [[tumor]] cells into [[immunocompromised]] mice, and is a research technique frequently used in pre-clinical [[oncology]] research.<ref name="Tentler 2012" />

Human xenotransplantation offers a potential treatment for end-stage [[organ failure]], a significant health problem in parts of the [[industrialized world]].  It also raises many novel medical, legal and ethical issues.<ref>{{cite journal | title = Xenotransplantation: Ethics and economics | last1 = Kress | first1 = J. M. | journal = Food and Drug Law Journal | volume = 53 | issue = 2 | pages = 353–384 | year = 1998| pmid = 10346691 }}</ref> A continuing concern is that many animals, such as [[pig]]s, have a shorter lifespan than humans, meaning that their tissues age at a quicker rate. (Pigs have a [[maximum life span]] of about 27 years.<ref name="pmid32361879">{{cite journal | vauthors = Hoffman J, Valencak TG | title = A short life on the farm: aging and longevity in agricultural, large-bodied mammals | journal = [[GeroScience]] | volume = 42 | issue = 3 | pages = 909–922 | date = 2020 | doi = 10.1007/s11357-020-00190-4 | pmc = 7286991 | pmid = 32361879}}</ref>) Disease transmission ([[xenozoonosis]]) and permanent alteration to the genetic code of animals are also causes for concern. Similarly to objections to [[animal testing]], animal rights activists have also objected to xenotransplantation on ethical grounds.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.pbs.org/wgbh/pages/frontline/shows/organfarm/interviews/lyons.html |title=Interviews - Dan Lyons |website=PBS |access-date=May 21, 2022}}</ref> A few temporarily successful cases of xenotransplantation are published.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.fda.gov/fdac/features/596_xeno.html  |title=Organ Transplants from Animals: Examining the Possibilities |publisher=Internet Archive |work=Fda.gov |url-status=dead|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20071210031618/https://www.fda.gov/fdac/features/596_xeno.html |archive-date = December 10, 2007|access-date=May 21, 2022}}</ref>

It is common for patients and physicians to use the term "allograft" imprecisely to refer to either allograft (human-to-human) or xenograft (animal-to-human), but it is helpful scientifically (for those searching or reading the [[scientific literature]]) to maintain the more precise distinction in [[usage]].{{cn|date=December 2023}}

Bioprosthetic [[artificial heart valves]] are generally pig or [[Bovinae|bovine]]-derived, but the cells are killed by glutaraldehyde treatment before insertion,<ref name="pmid31032263">{{cite journal| author=Li KYC| title=Bioprosthetic Heart Valves: Upgrading a 50-Year Old Technology. | journal=Front Cardiovasc Med | year= 2019 | volume= 6 | issue=  | pages= 47 | pmid=31032263 | doi=10.3389/fcvm.2019.00047 | pmc=6470412 | doi-access=free }}</ref> therefore technically not fulfilling the WHO definition of xenotransplantation of being live cells.<ref name=who/>

==History==
The first serious attempts at xenotransplantation (then called heterotransplantation) appeared in the scientific literature in 1905, when slices of rabbit kidney were transplanted into a child with [[chronic kidney disease]].<ref name=History1995>{{cite journal|title=Xenotransplantation: A Historical Perspective.|last1=Reemtsma|first1=K|journal=ILAR Journal|date=1995|volume=37|issue=1|pages=9–12|pmid=11528018|doi=10.1093/ilar.37.1.9|doi-access=free}}</ref> In the first two decades of the 20th century, several subsequent efforts to use organs from lambs, pigs, and primates were published.<ref name=History1995/>

Scientific interest in xenotransplantation declined when the [[immunological]] basis of the organ rejection process was described. The next waves of studies on the topic came with the discovery of [[immunosuppressive drug]]s.  Even more studies followed [[Joseph Murray]]'s first successful [[kidney transplantation|renal transplantation]] in 1954 and scientists, facing the ethical questions of organ donation for the first time, accelerated their effort in looking for alternatives to human organs.<ref name=History1995/>

=== Non-human kidney to a human ===
In 1963, doctors at [[Tulane University]] attempted [[Common chimpanzee|chimpanzee]]-to-human renal transplantations in six people who were near death; after this and several subsequent unsuccessful attempts to use primates as organ donors and the development of a working cadaver organ procuring program, interest in xenotransplantation for kidney failure dissipated.<ref name=History1995/>   Out of 13 such transplants performed by [[Keith Reemtsma]], one kidney recipient lived for nine months, returning to work as a schoolteacher. At autopsy, the chimpanzee kidneys appeared normal and showed no signs of acute or chronic rejection.<ref name="Cooper"/>

=== Non-human heart to a human ===
An American infant girl known as "[[Baby Fae]]" with [[hypoplastic left heart syndrome]] was the first infant recipient of a xenotransplantation, when she received a [[baboon]] heart in 1984. The procedure was performed by [[Leonard Lee Bailey]] at [[Loma Linda University Medical Center]] in [[Loma Linda, California]]. Fae died 21 days later due to a [[Humoral immunity|humoral-based]] [[graft rejection]] thought to be caused mainly by an ABO [[blood type]] mismatch, considered unavoidable due to the rarity of type O baboons. The graft was meant to be temporary, but unfortunately a suitable [[allograft]] replacement could not be found in time. While the procedure itself did not advance the progress on xenotransplantation, it did shed a light on the insufficient amount of organs for infants. The story made such an impact that the crisis of infant organ shortage improved for that time.<ref>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1001/jama.1985.03360230053022 | last1 = Bailey | first1 = L. L. | last2 = Nehlsen-Cannarella | first2 = S. L. | last3 = Concepcion | first3 = W. | last4 = Jolley | first4 = W. B. | title = Baboon-to-human cardiac xenotransplantation in a neonate | journal = JAMA: The Journal of the American Medical Association | volume = 254 | issue = 23 | pages = 3321–3329 | year = 1985 | pmid = 2933538}}</ref><ref name="Cooper">{{cite journal |title=A brief history of cross-species organ transplantation. |last1=Cooper |first1=DK |journal=Proceedings (Baylor University. Medical Center) | date=January 2012 |volume=25 |issue=1 |pages=49–57 |pmid=22275786|pmc=3246856 |doi=10.1080/08998280.2012.11928783 }}</ref>

=== Non-human heart, lungs, and kidneys to a human ===
The first transplant of a non-genetically modified<ref name="heartd">{{cite news|title=The heart of darkness|author=SCMP Reporter|newspaper=South China Morning Post|date=15 Feb 1997|language=en}}</ref><ref name="notmany">{{cite web|url=https://www.indiatoday.in/magazine/living/story/19970115-pig-heart-transplant-not-many-are-buying-the-assam-doctors-story-yet-831699-1997-01-15|title=Pig heart transplant: Not many are buying the Assam doctor's story yet|last=Banerjee|first=Ruben|date=January 15, 1997|website=India Today|access-date=May 21, 2022}}</ref> pig's heart, lungs and kidneys into a human was performed in [[Sonapur, Assam]], in [[India]] in mid-December 1996, and was announced in January 1997.<ref name="heartd" /> The recipient was Purno Saikia, a 32-year-old terminally-ill man; he died shortly after the operation of multiple infections.<ref name="heartd" /><ref>Maharashtra Herald, 11 Jan 11 1997, page 5</ref> The Indian [[cardiothoracic surgery|cardiothoracic surgeon]] [[Dhaniram Baruah|Dhani Ram Baruah]] and two of his associates, Jonathan Ho Kei-shing (of the Hong Kong-based Prince of Wales Medical Institute)<ref>{{cite news|title=Transplant surgeon to lose licence|author=Ruth Mathewson|newspaper=South China Morning Post|date=16 Feb 1997|language=en}}</ref> and C.S. James, performed the surgeries.<ref name="heartd" /> Baruah claimed that Saikia had failed to respond to conventional surgery, and that the patient and his family had consented to the procedure.<ref name="pigheart">{{cite news|url=https://science.thewire.in/the-sciences/university-maryland-pig-heart-xenotransplant-dhani-ram-baruah-1997-failed-surgery-arrest/|title=Why the US Pig Heart Transplant Was Different From the 1997 Assam Doc's Surgery|website=The Wire Science|date=January 13, 2022|access-date=May 21, 2022}}</ref>

All three involved in the surgery were arrested on January 9, 1997,<ref name="heartd" /> for the alleged violation of the [[Transplantation of Human Organs and Tissues Act, 1994|Transplantation of Human Organs and Tissues Act of 1994]].<ref name="heartd" /><ref>{{cite journal|title=Perspectives in Medical Ethics|author=M. Gnanapragasam|journal=Bioethics in India: Proceedings of the International Bioethics Workshop in Madras: Biomanagement of Biogeoresources|date=16–19 Jan 1997|publisher=University of Madras|language=en}}</ref> Baruah was dismissed in medical circles as a "mad scientist" and the procedure was dubbed a "hoax". Baruah himself signed a statement saying he had done no transplant, but then alleged that the confession was forced from him.<ref name="pigheart" /><ref name="notmany"/> They were found guilty of unethical procedure and [[culpable homicide]] and  imprisoned for 40 days.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.thehindu.com/sci-tech/science/assam-pioneer-of-pig-heart-transplant-now-working-on-biomolecular-treatment/article38266334.ece|title=A pig heart transplant in Assam in 1997|author=Rahul Karmakar|date=January 13, 2022|website=The Hindu|access-date=May 21, 2022}}</ref> Dhani Ram Baruah's surgical institute was also found to be without necessary registration.<ref>{{cite news|url=https://www.sentinelassam.com/north-east-india-news/assam-news/the-infamous-cardiac-surgeon-dr-dhani-ram-barua-all-you-need-to-know-560093|title=The Infamous Cardiac Surgeon - Dr Dhani Ram Baruah, All You Need To Know|website=The Sentinel (Guwahati)|date=October 23, 2021|access-date=May 21, 2022}}</ref>

Critics said Dhani Bam Baruah's claims and medical procedures were neither taken seriously nor accepted by the scientific community because he never got his findings scientifically [[Peer review|peer-reviewed]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://indianexpress.com/article/north-east-india/assam/pigs-heart-transplant-us-controversial-assam-doctor-7720434/|title=After pig's heart transplant in the US, controversial Assam doctor points out had done historic surgery 24 years ago|last=Agarwala|first=Tora|date=January 14, 2022|website=The Indian Express|access-date=May 21, 2022}}</ref> Past complaints of ethics violations during surgeries in Hong Kong by Baruah and Ho had occurred in 1992, when they had implanted heart valves, developed by Baruah, made of animal tissue. A year later, six patients died. The Asian Medical News reported that "grave concerns" were expressed "over the procedure and ethics of the implementation".<ref name="notmany"/>

=== Genetically engineered non-human kidney to a human ===
In September 2021, surgeons led by [[Robert Montgomery (physician)|Robert Montgomery]] performed the first genetically engineered pig [[Kidney transplantation|kidney]] xenotransplant to a brain-dead human at [[NYU Langone Health]] with no sign of immediate rejection (partly because the pig [[thymus gland]] was transplanted as well).<ref name="xeno">{{Cite web|url=https://nyulangone.org/news/progress-xenotransplantation-opens-door-new-supply-critically-needed-organs|title=Progress in Xenotransplantation Opens Door to New Supply of Critically Needed Organs|website=NYU Langone News|access-date=May 21, 2022}}</ref> The kidney was procured from a pig with only a single gene modification: the removal of [[Galactose-alpha-1,3-galactose|alpha-gal]].<ref>{{Cite web|url=https://www.usatoday.com/in-depth/news/health/2021/10/19/pig-kidney-organ-transplant-into-human-milestone-science/5948819001|title=Pig Kidneys to the Rescue? Groundbreaking Transplant a Step Toward Solving our Organ Shortage|last=Weintraub|first=Karen|date=October 19, 2021|website=USA Today|access-date=September 11, 2022}}</ref> 

In July 2023, surgeons from the NYU Langone Transplant Institute completed a transplant of a genetically modified pig kidney (along with the pig's [[Thymus|thymus gland]] underneath it) into a patient declared [[Brain death|brain dead]] but maintained on a respirator.<ref>{{Cite web |title=Pig Kidney Xenotransplantation Performing Optimally After 32 Days in Human Body |url=https://nyulangone.org/news/pig-kidney-xenotransplantation-performing-optimally-after-32-days-human-body |access-date=2023-08-17 |website=NYU Langone News |language=en}}</ref> The patient had previously consented to be an organ donor, but his tissues were not considered suitable for transplant. The kidney came from an animal with a [[Gene knockout|knocked-out gene]] for the production of [[Galactose-alpha-1,3-galactose|alpha gal]] sugars, which has been implicated in immune response to mammalian tissue.<ref>{{Cite journal |last1=Krishna |first1=N. |last2=Krishna |first2=S. |last3=Krishna |first3=R. |date=November 2017 |title=P112 Correlation between clinical findings and laboratory tests for alpha gal sensitivity |url=https://doi.org/10.1016/j.anai.2017.08.136 |journal=Annals of Allergy, Asthma & Immunology |volume=119 |issue=5 |pages=S37 |doi=10.1016/j.anai.2017.08.136 |issn=1081-1206}}</ref> In order to ensure that renal function was only supported by the pig kidney, the team removed both of the patient's kidneys. The team has reported that the kidney has maintained optimal functioning for over a month, as evidenced by routine testing of [[creatinine]] and weekly biopsies. The team plans to monitor the patient for another month, pending approval by ethics board and his family.{{cn|date=December 2023}}

In March 2024, [[Richard Slayman]], a patient whose transplanted human kidney had failed, received a genetically engineered pig kidney xenotransplant from surgeons at [[Massachusetts General Hospital]].<ref name="3/21/24nyt">{{cite news |last1=Rabin |first1=Roni Caryn |title=Surgeons Transplant Pig Kidney Into a Patient, a Medical Milestone |url=https://www.nytimes.com/2024/03/21/health/pig-kidney-organ-transplant.html |access-date=22 March 2024 |work=New York Times |date=21 March 2024}}</ref><ref name="3/21/24CNN">{{cite news |last1=Goodman |first1=Brenda |title=Pig kidney transplanted into living person for first time |url=https://www.cnn.com/2024/03/21/health/pig-kidney-transplant-living-person/index.html |access-date=22 March 2024 |work=CNN |date=21 March 2024 |language=en}}</ref>  This kidney has 69 genomic edits (3 gene knockout, 7 human gene insertion and 59 copies of the porcine retrovirus knockout) made by eGenesis, Inc.<ref>{{cite journal | vauthors = Anand RP, Layer JV, Heja D, et al | title = Design and testing of a humanized porcine donor for xenotransplantation | journal = Nature | volume = 622 | issue = 7982 | pages = 393–401 | date = 11 October 2023 | pmid = 37821590| doi = 10.1038/s41586-023-06594-4 | pmc = 10567564 }}</ref> Mr. Slayman died a few months later of unrelated causes, with no apparent rejection of the kidney.<ref name=npr24>{{cite news |title=The first person to receive a genetically modified pig kidney transplant has died |date=May 12, 2024 |author=Emma Bowman |publisher=[[NPR]] |url=https://www.npr.org/2024/05/12/1250835113/pig-kidney-transplant-richard-slayman |access-date=2024-05-13}}</ref>  Meanwhile, in April 2024, Lisa Pisano became the second person to receive such a kidney transplant.<ref name=npr24 /><ref name=nprpisano>{{cite news |title=A woman with failing kidneys receives genetically modified pig organs |date=April 24, 2024 |author=Rob Stein |publisher=NPR |url=https://www.npr.org/sections/health-shots/2024/04/24/1246577224/gene-edited-pig-kidney-transplant-nyu |access-date=2024-05-13}}</ref>

=== Genetically engineered non-human heart to a human ===
{{anchor|David Bennett}}
In January 2022, doctors led by cardiothoracic surgeon [[Bartley P. Griffith]] and [[Muhammad M. Mohiuddin]]<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.medschool.umaryland.edu/news/2022/University-of-Maryland-School-of-Medicine-Faculty-Scientists-and-Clinicians-Perform-Historic-First-Successful-Transplant-of-Porcine-Heart-into-Adult-Human-with-End-Stage-Heart-Disease.html|title=University of Maryland School of Medicine Faculty Scientists and Clinicians Perform Historic First Successful Transplant of Porcine Heart into Adult Human with End-Stage Heart Disease|last=Kotz|first=Deborah|date=January 10, 2022|website=[[University of Maryland School of Medicine]]|access-date=May 21, 2022}}</ref> at the [[University of Maryland Medical Center]] and [[University of Maryland School of Medicine]] performed a heart transplant from a genetically modified pig to a terminally ill patient, David Bennett Sr., who was ineligible for a standard human heart transplant. The pig had undergone specific gene editing to remove enzymes responsible for producing sugar antigens that lead to hyperacute organ rejection in humans. The US medical regulator gave special dispensation to carry out the procedure under [[compassionate use]] criteria.<ref name="griffith">{{cite web|url=https://www.bbc.com/news/world-us-canada-59944889|title=Man gets genetically-modified pig heart in world-first transplant|website=BBC News|date=January 11, 2022|access-date=May 21, 2022}}</ref> The recipient died two months after the transplantation.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://apnews.com/article/pig-heart-transplant-patient-dies-bc3b304de3c8d3bf3acbb3c221960ecf |title=US man who got 1st pig heart transplant dies after 2 months |last1=Neergaard |first1=Lauran |last2=Johnson |first2=Carla K. |website=Associated Press |date=March 9, 2022|access-date=May 21, 2022}}</ref>

In June and July 2022, surgeons at [[NYU Langone Health]] performed two genetically modified pig heart transplants into recently deceased humans.<ref>{{cite web|url=https://nyulangone.org/news/successful-heart-xenotransplant-experiments-nyu-langone-set-protocol-pig-human-organ-transplants|title=Successful Heart Xenotransplant Experiments at NYU Langone Set Protocol for Pig-to-Human Organ Transplants|last=DeVries|first=Colin|date=July 12, 2022|website=[[NYU Langone Health]]|access-date=September 11, 2022}}</ref> The hearts were from pigs that had the identical 10 genetic modifications used in the [[University of Maryland Medical Center]] heart xenotransplantation in January 2022. All three hearts came from Revivicor, Inc., a facility based in Blacksburg, Va., and a subsidiary of [[United Therapeutics]].<ref>{{cite web|url=https://www.statnews.com/2022/01/20/after-flurry-of-firsts-xenotransplantation-is-suddenly-back-in-spotlight/|title=After a Flurry of Firsts, Xenotransplantation is Suddenly Back in the Spotlight|last=Molteni|first=Megan|date=January 20, 2022|website=[[Stat News]]|access-date=September 11, 2022}}</ref>

On 20 September 2023, surgeons at the University of Maryland Medical Center in Baltimore performed a heart transplant from a genetically modified pig to Lawrence Faucette, a patient with terminal heart disease who was ineligible for a traditional heart transplant. On 30 October 2023, Faucette passed away after showing signs of organ rejection.<ref name=pigheart2>{{Cite web |agency=Associated Press |date=2023-11-01 |title=Man who received the second pig heart transplant dies, hospital says |url=https://www.nbcnews.com/news/us-news/man-received-second-pig-heart-transplant-dies-hospital-says-rcna123104 |access-date=2023-11-01 |website=www.nbcnews.com |language=en}}</ref>

==Potential uses==
A worldwide shortage of organs for clinical implantation causes about 20–35% of patients who need replacement organs to die on the waiting list.<ref>{{Cite journal | last1 = Healy | first1 = D. G. | last2 = Lawler | first2 = Z. | last3 = McEvoy | first3 = O. | last4 = Parlon | first4 = B. | last5 = Baktiari | first5 = N. | last6 = Egan | first6 = J. J. | last7 = Hurley | first7 = J. | last8 = McCarthy | first8 = J. F. | last9 = Mahon | first9 = N. | last10 = Wood | first10 = A. E. | title = Heart transplant candidates: Factors influencing waiting list mortality | journal = Irish Medical Journal | volume = 98 | issue = 10 | pages = 235–237 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16445141}}</ref> Certain procedures, some of which are being investigated in early clinical trials, aim to use cells or tissues from other species to treat life-threatening and debilitating illnesses such as [[cancer]], [[diabetes]], [[liver failure]] and [[Parkinson's disease]]. If [[Cryopreservation#Vitrification|vitrification]] can be perfected, it could allow for long-term storage of xenogenic cells, tissues and organs so that they would be more readily available for transplant.{{citation needed|date=May 2022}}

Xenotransplants could save thousands of patients waiting for donated organs. The animal organ, probably from a pig or baboon could be [[Genetic engineering|genetically altered]] with human genes to trick a patient's immune system into accepting it as a part of its own body.<ref name="Sachs"/> They have re-emerged because of the lack of organs available and the constant battle to keep immune systems from [[Transplant rejection|rejecting]] allotransplants. Xenotransplants are thus potentially a more effective alternative.<ref>{{cite journal|vauthors=Platt JL, Cascalho M |title= New and old technologies for organ replacement|journal= Current Opinion in Organ Transplantation|volume= 18|issue= 2|pages= 179–85|pmid=23449347|year= 2013|doi= 10.1097/MOT.0b013e32835f0887|pmc=4911019}}</ref><ref>{{cite journal|pmc=3501885 |pmid= 23172951|year= 2012|last1= Van Der Windt|first1= D. J.|title= Clinical islet xenotransplantation: How close are we?|journal= Diabetes|volume= 61|issue= 12|pages= 3046–55|last2= Bottino|first2= R|last3= Kumar|first3= G|last4= Wijkstrom|first4= M|last5= Hara|first5= H|last6= Ezzelarab|first6= M|last7= Ekser|first7= B|last8= Phelps|first8= C|last9= Murase|first9= N|last10= Casu|first10= A|last11= Ayares|first11= D|last12= Lakkis|first12= F. G.|last13= Trucco|first13= M|last14= Cooper|first14= D. K.|doi= 10.2337/db12-0033}}</ref><ref>{{cite book|vauthors=Tisato V, Cozzi E |title=Xenotransplantation |journal=<!-- Citation bot bypass--> |volume= 885|pages= 1–16|pmid=22565986|year= 2012|doi= 10.1007/978-1-61779-845-0_1|chapter= Xenotransplantation: An Overview of the Field|series=Methods in Molecular Biology |isbn=978-1-61779-844-3 }}</ref>

Xenotransplantation of human tumor cells into immunocompromised mice is a research technique frequently used in oncology research.<ref>{{cite journal|last1=Richmond|first1=A.|last2=Su|first2=Y.|year=2008|title=Mouse xenograft models vs GEM models for human cancer therapeutics|journal=Disease Models and Mechanisms|volume=1|issue=2–3|pages=78–82|doi=10.1242/dmm.000976|pmc=2562196|pmid=19048064}}</ref> It is used to predict the sensitivity of the transplanted tumor to various cancer treatments; several companies offer this service, including the [[Jackson Laboratory]].<ref>[https://web.archive.org/web/20081123090324/http://jaxmice.jax.org/jaxnotes/508/508d.html JAX® In Vivo Xenograft Services]. ''JAX® NOTES'' Issue 508, Winter 2008</ref>

Human organs have been transplanted into animals as a powerful research technique for studying [[human biology]] without harming human patients. This technique has also been proposed as an alternative source of human organs for future transplantation into human patients.<ref>{{cite web|last=Lewis|first=Tanya|date=2015-01-21|title=Growing human kidneys in rats sparks ethical debate|url=http://www.cbsnews.com/news/growing-human-kidneys-in-rats-sparks-ethical-debate/|access-date=2015-09-26|publisher=CBS News}}</ref> For example, researchers from the [[Ganogen Research Institute]] transplanted [[human]] [[fetal]] [[kidneys]] into rats which demonstrated life supporting function and growth.<ref name="Tentler 2012">{{cite journal|pmid=22508028|pmc=3928688|doi=10.1038/nrclinonc.2012.61|year=2012|last1=Tentler|first1=J. J.|title=Patient-derived tumour xenografts as models for oncology drug development|journal=Nature Reviews. Clinical Oncology|volume=9|issue=6|pages=338–50|last2=Tan|first2=A. C.|last3=Weekes|first3=C. D.|last4=Jimeno|first4=A|last5=Leong|first5=S|last6=Pitts|first6=T. M.|last7=Arcaroli|first7=J. J.|last8=Messersmith|first8=W. A.|last9=Eckhardt|first9=S. G.}}</ref>

== Potential animal organ donors ==
Since they are the closest relatives to humans, non-human primates were first considered as a potential organ source for xenotransplantation to humans. [[Chimpanzee]]s were originally considered the best option since their organs are of similar size, and they have good blood type compatibility with humans, which makes them potential candidates for [[xenotransfusion]]s. However, since chimpanzees are listed as an [[endangered species]], other potential donors were sought. [[Baboon]]s are more readily available, but impractical as potential donors. Problems include their smaller body size, the infrequency of blood group O (the universal donor), their long gestation period, and their typically small number of offspring. In addition, a major problem with the use of nonhuman primates is the increased risk of disease transmission, since they are so closely related to humans.<ref name=michler1996>{{Cite journal | last1 = Michler | first1 = R. | title = Xenotransplantation: Risks, Clinical Potential, and Future Prospects | doi = 10.3201/eid0201.960111 | journal = Emerging Infectious Diseases | volume = 2 | issue = 1 | pages = 64–70 | year = 1996 | pmid = 8903201 | pmc =2639801 }}</ref>

[[Domestic pig|Pig]]s (''Sus scrofa domesticus'') are currently thought to be the best candidates for organ donation. The risk of cross-species disease transmission is decreased because of their increased phylogenetic distance from humans.<ref name=Dooldeniya2003 /> Pigs have relatively short gestation periods, large litters, and are easy to breed, making them readily available.<ref name="Will Genetic Engineering Carry Xeno">{{cite journal |last1=Kemter |first1=Elisabeth |last2=Denner |first2=Joachim |last3=Wolf |first3=Eckhard |title=Will Genetic Engineering Carry Xenotransplantation of Pig Islets to the Clinic? |journal=Current Diabetes Reports |date=2018 |volume=18 |issue=11 |page=103 | doi = 10.1007/s11892-018-1074-5 |pmid=30229378|s2cid=52308812 }}</ref>
They are inexpensive and easy to maintain in pathogen-free facilities, and current gene editing tools are adapted to pigs to combat rejection and potential [[zoonoses]].<ref name="Will Genetic Engineering Carry Xeno"/> Pig organs are anatomically comparable in size, and new infectious agents are less likely since they have been in close contact with humans through domestication for many generations.<ref name=Taylor2007>Taylor, L. (2007) [http://www.emedicine.com/med/topic3715.htm Xenotransplantation]. Emedicine.com</ref> Treatments sourced from pigs have proven to be successful such as porcine-derived insulin for patients with diabetes mellitus.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Cooper |first1=David |last2=Ekser |first2=Burcin |last3=Ramsoondar |first3=Jagdeece |last4=Phelps |first4=Carol |last5=Ayares |first5=David |title=The role of genetically engineered pigs in xenotransplantation research |journal=The Journal of Pathology |date=2015 |volume=238 |issue=2 |pages=288–299 | doi = 10.1002/path.4635|pmid=26365762 |pmc=4689670 |doi-access=free }}</ref> Increasingly, genetically engineered pigs are becoming the norm, which raises moral qualms, but also increases the success rate of the transplant.<ref name="reiss">{{Cite journal|last=REISS|first=MICHAEL J.|date=2000|title=The Ethics of Xenotransplantation|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/24354019|journal=Journal of Applied Philosophy|volume=17|issue=3|pages=253–262|doi=10.1111/1468-5930.00160|jstor=24354019|pmid=11765766|issn=0264-3758}}</ref>
Current experiments in xenotransplantation most often use pigs as the donor, and baboons as human models. In 2020 the U.S. [[Food and Drug Administration]] approved a genetic modification of pigs so they do not produce [[Galactose-alpha-1,3-galactose|alpha-gal]] sugars.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Dolgin|first=Elie|date=2021-04-01|title=First GM pigs for allergies. Could xenotransplants be next?|url=https://www.nature.com/articles/s41587-021-00885-9|journal=Nature Biotechnology|language=en|volume=39|issue=4|pages=397–400|doi=10.1038/s41587-021-00885-9|pmid=33846652|s2cid=233223010|issn=1546-1696}}</ref> Pig organs have been used for kidney and heart transplants into humans.<ref name="griffith" /><ref name="xeno"/><ref name="3/21/24nyt" /><ref name=nprpisano /><ref name=pigheart2 />

==Barriers and issues==

=== Immunologic barriers ===
To date,{{citation needed|date=April 2022}} no xenotransplantation trials have been entirely successful due to the many obstacles arising from the response of the recipient's [[immune system]]. Xenozoonoses are one of the biggest threats to rejections, as they are xenogenetic infections. The introduction of these microorganisms are a big issue that lead to the fatal infections and then rejection of the organs.<ref>{{cite journal |last1=Boneva |first1=RS |last2=Folks |first2=TM |last3=Chapman |first3=LE |title=Infectious disease issues in xenotransplantation. |journal=Clinical Microbiology Reviews |date=January 2001 |volume=14 |issue=1 |pages=1–14 |doi=10.1128/CMR.14.1.1-14.2001 |pmid=11148000|pmc=88959 }}</ref> This response, which is generally more extreme than in allotransplantations, ultimately results in rejection of the xenograft, and can in some cases result in the immediate death of the recipient. There are several types of rejection organ xenografts are faced with, these include hyperacute rejection, acute vascular rejection, cellular rejection, and chronic rejection.{{citation needed|date=April 2022}}

A rapid, violent, and hyperacute response comes as a result of [[antibodies]] present in the host organism. These antibodies are known as xenoreactive natural antibodies (XNAs).<ref name=Dooldeniya2003/>

==== Hyperacute rejection ====

This rapid and violent type of rejection occurs within minutes to hours from the time of the transplant. It is mediated by the binding of XNAs (xenoreactive natural antibodies) to the donor endothelium, causing activation of the human [[complement system]], which results in endothelial damage, inflammation, thrombosis and necrosis of the transplant. XNAs are first produced and begin circulating in the blood in neonates, after colonization of the bowel by bacteria with galactose moieties on their cell walls. Most of these antibodies are the [[IgM]] class, but also include [[IgG]], and [[IgA]].<ref name="Taylor2007"/>

The epitope XNAs target is an α-linked galactose moiety, [[galactose-alpha-1,3-galactose]] (also called the α-Gal epitope), produced by the enzyme alpha-[[galactosyltransferase]].<ref name=candinas2000>{{Cite journal | last1 = Candinas | first1 = D. | last2 = Adams | first2 = D. H. | title = Xenotransplantation: Postponed by a millennium? | doi = 10.1093/qjmed/93.2.63 | journal = QJM | volume = 93 | issue = 2 | pages = 63–66 | year = 2000 | pmid =  10700475| doi-access = free }}</ref> Most non-primates contain this enzyme thus, this epitope is present on the organ epithelium and is perceived as a foreign [[antigen]] by primates, which lack the galactosyl transferase enzyme. In pig to primate xenotransplantation, XNAs recognize porcine glycoproteins of the integrin family.<ref name="Taylor2007"/>

The binding of XNAs initiate complement activation through the [[classical complement pathway]]. Complement activation causes a cascade of events leading to: destruction of endothelial cells, platelet degranulation, inflammation, coagulation, fibrin deposition, and hemorrhage. The result is [[thrombosis]] and [[necrosis]] of the xenograft.<ref name="Taylor2007"/>

==== Overcoming hyperacute rejection ====
Since hyperacute rejection presents such a barrier to the success of xenografts, several strategies to overcome it are under investigation:

''Interruption of the complement cascade''
* The recipient's complement cascade can be inhibited through the use of cobra venom factor (which depletes [[C3-convertase|C3]]), soluble complement receptor type 1, anti-[[Complement component 5|C5]] antibodies, or [[C1 inhibitor]] (C1-INH). Disadvantages of this approach include the toxicity of cobra venom factor, and most importantly these treatments would deprive the individual of a functional complement system.<ref name="Dooldeniya2003"/>

''Transgenic organs (Genetically engineered pigs)''
* 1,3 galactosyl transferase gene knockouts – These pigs do not contain the gene that codes for the enzyme responsible for expression of the immunogeneic gal-α-1,3Gal moiety (the α-Gal epitope).<ref name=latemple>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1399-3089.1998.tb00027.x | last1 = Latemple | first1 = D. C. | last2 = Galili | first2 = U. | title = Adult and neonatal anti-Gal response in knock-out mice for alpha1,3galactosyltransferase | journal = Xenotransplantation | volume = 5 | issue = 3 | pages = 191–196 | year = 1998 | pmid = 9741457| s2cid = 39194181 }}</ref>
* Increased expression of H-transferase ([[α-1,2-fucosyltransferase]]), an enzyme that competes with galactosyl transferase. Experiments have shown this reduces α-Gal expression by 70%.<ref name=sharma>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1073/pnas.93.14.7190 | last1 = Sharma | first1 = A. | last2 = Okabe | first2 = J. | last3 = Birch | first3 = P. | last4 = McClellan | first4 = S. B. | last5 = Martin | first5 = M. J. | last6 = Platt | first6 = J. L. | last7 = Logan | first7 = J. S. | title = Reduction in the level of Gal(alpha1,3)Gal in transgenic mice and pigs by the expression of an alpha(1,2)fucosyltransferase | journal = Proceedings of the National Academy of Sciences of the United States of America | volume = 93 | issue = 14 | pages = 7190–7195 | year = 1996 | pmid = 8692967 | pmc = 38958| bibcode = 1996PNAS...93.7190S | doi-access = free }}</ref>
* Expression of human complement regulators ([[CD55]], [[CD46]], and [[CD59]]) to inhibit the complement cascade.<ref name=huang>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1111/j.1574-695X.2001.tb00521.x | last1 = Huang | first1 = J. | last2 = Gou | first2 = D. | last3 = Zhen | first3 = C. | last4 = Jiang | first4 = D. | last5 = Mao | first5 = X. | last6 = Li | first6 = W. | last7 = Chen | first7 = S. | last8 = Cai | first8 = C. | title = Protection of xenogeneic cells from human complement-mediated lysis by the expression of human DAF, CD59 and MCP | journal = FEMS Immunology and Medical Microbiology | volume = 31 | issue = 3 | pages = 203–209 | year = 2001 | pmid = 11720816| doi-access = free }}</ref>
* Plasmaphoresis, on humans to remove 1,3 galactosyltransferase, reduces the risk of activation of effector cells such as CTL (CD8 T cells), complement pathway activation and delayed type hypersensitivity (DTH).

====Acute vascular rejection====

Also known as delayed xenoactive rejection, this type of rejection occurs in discordant xenografts within 2 to 3 days, if hyperacute rejection is prevented. The process is much more complex than hyperacute rejection and is currently not completely understood. Acute vascular rejection requires de novo protein synthesis and is driven by interactions between the graft endothelial cells and host antibodies, macrophages, and platelets. The response is characterized by an inflammatory infiltrate of mostly [[macrophages]] and [[natural killer cells]] (with small numbers of [[T cells]]), intravascular thrombosis, and fibrinoid necrosis of vessel walls.<ref name="candinas2000"/>

Binding of the previously mentioned XNAs to the donor endothelium leads to the activation of host macrophages as well as the endothelium itself. The endothelium activation is considered type II since gene induction and protein synthesis are involved. The binding of XNAs ultimately leads to the development of a procoagulant state, the secretion of inflammatory [[cytokines]] and [[chemokines]], as well as expression of leukocyte adhesion molecules such as [[E-selectin]], intercellular adhesion molecule-1 ([[ICAM-1]]), and vascular cell adhesion molecule-1 ([[VCAM-1]]).<ref name="Taylor2007"/>

This response is further perpetuated as normally binding between regulatory proteins and their ligands aid in the control of coagulation and inflammatory responses. However, due to molecular incompatibilities between the molecules of the donor species and recipient (such as porcine [[major histocompatibility complex]] molecules and human natural killer cells), this may not occur.<ref name="candinas2000"/>

==== Overcoming acute vascular rejection ====
Due to its complexity,  the use of immunosuppressive drugs along with a wide array of approaches are necessary to prevent acute vascular rejection, and include administering a synthetic thrombin inhibitor to modulate thrombogenesis, depletion of anti-galactose antibodies (XNAs) by techniques such as immunoadsorption, to prevent endothelial cell activation, and inhibiting activation of macrophages (stimulated by CD4<sup>+</sup> T cells) and NK cells (stimulated by the release of Il-2). Thus, the role of MHC molecules and T cell responses in activation would have to be reassessed for each species combo.<ref name="candinas2000"/>

==== Accommodation ====
If hyperacute and acute vascular rejection are avoided accommodation is possible, which is the survival of the xenograft despite the presence of circulating XNAs. The graft is given a break from humoral rejection<ref name=takahashi>{{Cite journal | last1 = Takahashi | first1 = T. | last2 = Saadi | first2 = S. | last3 = Platt | first3 = J. L. | doi = 10.1007/BF02786395 | title = Recent advances in the immunology of xenotransplantation | journal = Immunologic Research | volume = 16 | issue = 3 | pages = 273–297 | year = 1997 | pmid = 9379077 | s2cid = 46479950 }}</ref> when the complement cascade is interrupted, circulating antibodies are removed, or their function is changed, or there is a change in the expression of surface antigens on the graft. This allows the xenograft to up-regulate and express protective genes, which aid in resistance to injury, such as [[heme oxygenase-1]] (an enzyme that catalyzes the degradation of heme).<ref name="Taylor2007"/>

==== Cellular rejection ====
Rejection of the xenograft in hyperacute and acute vascular rejection is due to the response of the [[humoral immune system]], since the response is elicited by the XNAs. Cellular rejection is based on [[cellular immunity]], and is mediated by natural killer cells that accumulate in and damage the xenograft and T-lymphocytes which are activated by MHC molecules through both direct and indirect xenorecognition.{{cn|date=December 2023}}

In direct xenorecognition, antigen presenting cells from the xenograft present peptides to recipient CD4<sup>+</sup> T cells via xenogeneic MHC class II molecules, resulting in the production of [[interleukin 2]] (IL-2). Indirect xenorecognition involves the presentation of antigens from the xenograft by recipient antigen presenting cells to CD4<sup>+</sup> T cells. Antigens of phagocytosed graft cells can also be presented by the host's class I MHC molecules to CD8<sup>+</sup> T cells.<ref name=Dooldeniya2003/><ref name=abbas2005>Abbas, A., Lichtman, A. (2005) ''Cellular and Molecular Immunology'', 5th ed., pp. 81, 330–333, 381, 386. Elsevier Saunders, Pennsylvania,{{ISBN|0-7216-0008-5}}, {{doi|10.1002/bmb.2004.494032019997}}.</ref>

The strength of cellular rejection in xenografts remains uncertain, however, it is expected to be stronger than in allografts due to differences in peptides among different animals. This leads to more antigens potentially recognized as foreign, thus eliciting a greater indirect xenogenic response.<ref name="Dooldeniya2003"/>

==== Overcoming cellular rejection ====
A proposed strategy to avoid cellular rejection is to induce donor non-responsiveness using hematopoietic chimerism.<ref name="Sachs">{{cite journal | journal=Xenotransplantation | date = May 2018 | volume=25 |issue=3 |page=e12420 | pmid= 29913045 | title=Transplantation Tolerance Through Mixed Chimerism: From Allo to Xeno | author=David H. Sachs| doi = 10.1111/xen.12420 | pmc = 6010074 }}</ref> Donor stem cells are introduced into the bone marrow of the recipient, where they coexist with the recipient's stem cells. The bone marrow stem cells give rise to cells of all hematopoietic lineages, through the process of [[hematopoiesis]]. Lymphoid progenitor cells are created by this process and move to the thymus where negative selection eliminates T cells found to be reactive to self. The existence of donor stem cells in the recipient's bone marrow causes donor reactive T cells to be considered self and undergo [[apoptosis]].<ref name="Dooldeniya2003"/>

==== Chronic rejection ====
Chronic rejection is slow and progressive, and usually occurs in transplants that survive the initial rejection phases.<ref name="candinas2000" /> Scientists are still unclear how chronic rejection exactly works, research in this area is difficult since xenografts rarely survive past the initial acute rejection phases. Nonetheless, it is known that XNAs and the complement system are not primarily involved.<ref name="candinas2000"/> [[Fibrosis]] in the xenograft occurs as a result of immune reactions, cytokines (which stimulate fibroblasts), or healing (following cellular necrosis in acute rejection). Perhaps the major cause of chronic rejection is [[arteriosclerosis]]. Lymphocytes, which were previously activated by antigens in the vessel wall of the graft, activate macrophages to secrete smooth muscle growth factors. This results in a build up of smooth muscle cells on the vessel walls, causing the hardening and narrowing of vessels within the graft. Chronic rejection leads to pathologic changes of the organ, and is why transplants must be replaced after so many years.<ref name="abbas2005"/> It is also anticipated that chronic rejection will be more aggressive in xenotransplants as opposed to allotransplants.<ref name=vanderpool>{{Cite journal | last1 = Vanderpool | first1 = H. Y. | title = Xenotransplantation: Progress and promise | doi = 10.1136/bmj.319.7220.1311 | journal = BMJ | volume = 319 | issue = 7220 | page = 1311 | year = 1999 | pmid =  10559062| pmc =1129087 }}</ref>

==== Dysregulated coagulation ====
Successful efforts have been made to create knockout mice without α1,3GT; the resulting reduction in the highly immunogenic αGal epitope has resulted in the reduction of the occurrence of hyperacute rejection, but has not eliminated other barriers to xenotransplantation such as dysregulated coagulation, also known as [[coagulopathy]].<ref name="cowan2011">{{cite journal|author1=Cowan PJ |author2=Robson SC |author3=d'Apice AJF |title=Controlling coagulation dysregulation in xenotransplantation|journal=Current Opinion in Organ Transplantation|volume=16|issue=2|pages=214–21|pmid=21415824|pmc=3094512|year=2011|doi=10.1097/MOT.0b013e3283446c65}}</ref>

Different organ xenotransplants result in different responses in clotting. For example, kidney transplants result in a higher degree of [[coagulopathy]], or impaired clotting, than cardiac transplants, whereas liver xenografts result in severe [[thrombocytopenia]], causing recipient death within a few days due to bleeding.<ref name="cowan2011" /> An alternate clotting disorder, [[thrombosis]], may be initiated by preexisting antibodies that affect the protein C anticoagulant system. Due to this effect, porcine donors must be extensively screened before transplantation. Studies have also shown that some porcine transplant cells are able to induce human tissue factor expression, thus stimulating platelet and monocyte aggregation around the xenotransplanted organ, causing severe clotting.<ref name="ekser2010">{{cite journal|vauthors=Ekser B, Cooper DK|title=Overcoming the barriers to xenotransplantation: prospects for the future|journal=Expert Review of Clinical Immunology|volume=6|issue=2|pages=219–30|pmid=20402385|pmc=2857338|year=2010|doi=10.1586/eci.09.81}}</ref> Additionally, spontaneous platelet accumulation may be caused by contact with pig von Willebrand factor.<ref name="ekser2010" />

Just as the α1,3G epitope is a major problem in xenotransplantation, so too is dysregulated coagulation a cause of concern. Transgenic pigs that can control for variable coagulant activity based on the specific organ transplanted would make xenotransplantation a more readily available solution for the 70,000 patients per year who do not receive a human donation of the organ or tissue they need.<ref name="ekser2010" />

=== Physiology ===
Extensive research is required to determine whether animal organs can replace the physiological functions of human organs. Many issues include:
* size – with pigs for example, organs are taken from young pigs to be of suitable size for donation, and these may still be able to grow afterwards <ref name="Dooldeniya2003" />
* longevity – the lifespan of most pigs is roughly 15 years, currently it is unknown how xenotransplanted organs age<ref name="Dooldeniya2003" />
* hormone and protein differences – some proteins will be molecularly incompatible, which could cause malfunction of important regulatory processes. These differences also make the prospect of hepatic xenotransplantation less promising, since the liver plays an important role in the production of so many proteins<ref name="Dooldeniya2003" /><ref name="candinas2000" />
* environment – for example, pig hearts work in a different anatomical site and under different hydrostatic pressure than in humans<ref name="candinas2000" />
* temperature – the body temperature of pigs is 39 °C (2 °C above the average human body temperature). Implications of this difference, if any, on the activity of important enzymes are currently unknown.<ref name="Dooldeniya2003" />

===Xenozoonosis===
Xenozoonosis, also known as [[zoonosis]] or xenosis, is the transmission of infectious agents between species via xenograft. Animal to human infection is normally rare, but has occurred in the past. An example of such is the [[avian influenza]], when an influenza A virus was passed from birds to humans.<ref name=who2005>{{Cite journal | last1 = Beigel | first1 = J. | last2 = Farrar | first2 = J. | last3 = Han | first3 = A. | last4 = Hayden | first4 = F. | last5 = Hyer | first5 = R. | last6 = De Jong | first6 = M. | last7 = Lochindarat | first7 = S. | last8 = Nguyen | first8 = T. | last9 = Nguyen | first9 = T. | last10 = Tran | first10 = T. H. | last11 = Nicoll | first11 = A. | last12 = Touch | first12 = S. | last13 = Yuen | first13 = K. Y. | author14 = Writing Committee of the World Health Organization (WHO) Consultation on Human Influenza A/H5 | title = Avian Influenza A (H5N1) Infection in Humans | journal = New England Journal of Medicine | volume = 353 | issue = 13 | pages = 1374–1385 | year = 2005 | pmid = 16192482 | doi = 10.1056/NEJMra052211| citeseerx = 10.1.1.730.7890 }}</ref> Xenotransplantation may increase the chance of disease transmission for 3 reasons: (1) implantation breaches the physical barrier that normally helps to prevent disease transmission, (2) the recipient of the transplant will be severely immunosuppressed, and (3) human complement regulators (CD46, CD55, and CD59) expressed in transgenic pigs have been shown to serve as virus receptors, and may also help to protect viruses from attack by the complement system.<ref name=takeuchi2000>{{Cite journal | doi = 10.1016/S0952-7915(00)00128-X | last1 = Takeuchi | first1 = Y. | last2 = Weiss | first2 = R. A. | title = Xenotransplantation: Reappraising the risk of retroviral zoonosis | journal = Current Opinion in Immunology | volume = 12 | issue = 5 | pages = 504–507 | year = 2000 | pmid = 11007351}}</ref>

Examples of viruses carried by pigs include porcine [[herpesvirus]], [[rotavirus]], [[parvovirus]], and [[circovirus]]. Porcine herpesviruses and rotaviruses can be eliminated from the donor pool by screening, however others (such as parvovirus and circovirus) may contaminate food and footwear then re-infect the herd. Thus, pigs to be used as organ donors must be housed under strict regulations and screened regularly for microbes and pathogens. Unknown viruses, as well as those not harmful in the animal, may also pose risks.<ref name=takeuchi2000 /> Of particular concern are PERVS (porcine endogenous retroviruses), vertically transmitted microbes that embed in swine genomes. The risks with xenosis are twofold, as not only could the individual become infected, but a novel infection could initiate an epidemic in the human population. Because of this risk, the FDA has suggested any recipients of xenotransplants shall be closely monitored for the remainder of their life, and quarantined if they show signs of xenosis.<ref name=FDA2006>FDA. (2006) [https://www.fda.gov/cber/xap/xap.htm Xenotransplantation Action Plan: FDA Approach to the Regulation of Xenotransplantation]. Center for Biologics Evaluation and Research.</ref>

Baboons and pigs carry myriad transmittable agents that are harmless in their natural host, but extremely toxic and deadly in humans. HIV is an example of a disease believed to have jumped from monkeys to humans. Researchers also do not know if an outbreak of infectious diseases could occur and if they could contain the outbreak even though they have measures for control. Another obstacle facing xenotransplants is that of the body's rejection of foreign objects by its immune system. These antigens (foreign objects) are often treated with powerful immunosuppressive drugs that could, in turn, make the patient vulnerable to other infections and actually aid the disease. This is the reason the organs would have to be altered to fit the patients' DNA ([[histocompatibility]]).{{cn|date=December 2023}}

In 2005, the Australian [[National Health and Medical Research Council]] (NHMRC) declared an eighteen-year moratorium on all animal-to-human transplantation, concluding that the risks of transmission of animal viruses to patients and the wider community had not been resolved.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.nhmrc.gov.au/about/committees/expert/gtrap/_files/xenotrans.pdf |title=The Australian National Health and Medical Research Council's 2005 statement on xenotransplantation |access-date=2008-11-06 |archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20080722120810/http://nhmrc.gov.au/about/committees/expert/gtrap/_files/xenotrans.pdf |archive-date = 2008-07-22}}</ref>
This was repealed in 2009 after an NHMRC review stated "... the risks, if appropriately regulated, are minimal and acceptable given the potential benefits.", citing international developments on the management and regulation of xenotransplantation by the World Health Organisation and the European Medicines Agency.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.lifescientist.com.au/article/329402/xenotransplantation_ban_lifted_australia |title=Xenotransplantation ban lifted in Australia |work=Life Scientist|last=Dean |first=Tim |date=December 10, 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20091215005407/http://www.lifescientist.com.au/article/329402/xenotransplantation_ban_lifted_australia |archive-date=2009-12-15 |access-date=May 21, 2022}}</ref>

===Ethics===
Xenografts have been a controversial procedure since they were first attempted. Many, including animal rights groups, strongly oppose killing animals to harvest their organs for human use.<ref>[http://www.peta.org/mc/factsheet_display.asp?ID=82 PETA Media Center: Factsheet: Xenotransplantation] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20100626072643/http://www.peta.org/mc/factsheet_display.asp?ID=82 |date=June 26, 2010 }}. Peta.org. Retrieved on 2013-10-17.</ref>  In the 1960s, many organs came from the chimpanzees, and were transferred into people that were deathly ill, and in turn, did not live much longer afterwards.<ref>{{Cite book|last=Sharp|first=Leslie|title=The Transplant Imaginary Mechanical Hearts, Animal Parts, and Moral Thinking in Highly Experimental Science.|publisher=University of California Press|year=2013|isbn=9780520277960|pages=38}}</ref> Modern scientific supporters of xenotransplantation argue that the potential benefits to society outweigh the risks, making pursuing xenotransplantation the moral choice.<ref>{{Cite journal|last1=Cooper|first1=David K. C.|last2=Groth|first2=Carl G.|last3=McKenzie|first3=Ian F. C.|last4=Goldman|first4=Emanuel|last5=Fano|first5=Alix|last6=Vanderpool|first6=Harold Y.|date=2000|title=Xenotransplantation|journal=BMJ: British Medical Journal|volume=320|issue=7238|pages=868–869|doi=10.1136/bmj.320.7238.868|jstor=25187509|pmid=10731189|pmc=1127208|issn=0959-8138}}</ref> None of the major religions object to the use of genetically modified pig organs for life-saving transplantation.<ref>{{cite book |last=Rothblatt |first=Martine |date=2004 |title=Your Life or Mine |location=Burlington, VT |publisher=Ashgate Publishing Company |pages=109–110 |isbn=978-0754623915 }}</ref> Religions such as [[Buddhism]] and [[Jainism]], however, have long espoused non-violence towards all living creatures.<ref name="reiss" />
In general, the use of pig and cow tissue in humans has been met with little resistance, save some religious beliefs and a few philosophical objections. Experimentation without consent doctrines are now followed, which was not the case in the past, which may lead to new religious guidelines to further medical research on pronounced ecumenical guidelines. The "Common Rule" is the United States bio-ethics mandate {{as of|2011|lc=y}}.<ref>von Derdidas, Ihrwir (2009) [http://hotelstgeorgepress.com/2010/05/a-more-modest-proposal/ A More Modest Proposal] {{webarchive |url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110712221956/http://hotelstgeorgepress.com/2010/05/a-more-modest-proposal/ |date=July 12, 2011 }}.  Hotel St. George Press.</ref>

====History of xenotransplantation in ethics====
At the beginning of the 20th century when studies in xenotransplantation were just beginning, few questioned the morality of it, turning to animals as a "natural" alternative to [[Allotransplantation|allografts]].<ref name="anissue">{{Cite journal|last=Rémy|first=Catherine|date=2009|title=The Animal Issue in Xenotransplantation: Controversies in France and the United States|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/23334492|journal=History and Philosophy of the Life Sciences|volume=31|issue=3/4|pages=405–428|jstor=23334492|pmid=20586139 |issn=0391-9714}}</ref> While [[Satire|satirical plays]] mocked xenografters such as [[Serge Voronoff]], and some images showing emotionally distraught primates appeared – who Voronoff had deprived of their testicles – no serious attempts were yet made to question the science based on animal rights concerns.<ref name="anissue" /> Xenotransplantation was not taken seriously, at least in France, during the first half of the 20th century.<ref name="anissue" />

With the Baby Fae incident of 1984 as the impetus, animal rights activists began to protest, gathering media attention and proving that some people felt that it was unethical and a violation of the animal's own rights to use its organs to preserve a sick human's life.<ref name="anissue" /> Treating animals as mere tools for the slaughter on demand by human will would lead to a world they would not prefer.<ref name="anissue" /> Supporters of the transplant pushed back, claiming that saving a human life justifies the sacrifice of an animal one.<ref name="anissue" /> Most animal rights activists found the use of primate organs more reprehensible than those of, for example, pigs.<ref name="anissue" /> As [[Peter Singer]] et al. have expressed, many primates exhibit greater social structure, communication skills, and affection than mentally deficient humans and human infants.<ref>{{Cite journal|last=Anderson|first=M.|date=2006|title=Xenotransplantation: A Bioethical Evaluation|url= |journal=Journal of Medical Ethics|volume=32|issue=4|pages=205–208|doi=10.1136/jme.2005.012914|pmid=16574873|issn=0306-6800|pmc=2565783}}</ref> Despite this, it is considerably unlikely that animal suffering will provide sufficient impetus for regulators to prevent xenotransplantation.<ref name="reiss"/>

==== Informed consent of patient ====
[[Autonomy]] and [[informed consent]] are important when considering the future uses of xenotransplantation. A patient undergoing xenotransplantation should be fully aware of the procedure and should have no outside force influencing their choice.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Ellison T. |title=Xenotransplantation—ethics and regulation|journal=Xenotransplantation|volume=13|issue=6|pages=505–9|pmid=17059575|year=2006|doi=10.1111/j.1399-3089.2006.00352_3.x|s2cid=9831264}}</ref> The patient should understand the risks and benefits of such a transplantation. A [[public health]] dimension can also be considered.<ref>{{cite journal|author=Kaiser M. |title=Xenotransplantation—ethical considerations based on human and societal perspectives|journal=Acta Veterinaria Scandinavica. Supplementum|volume=99|pages=65–73|pmid=15347151|year=2004}}</ref>

The Ethics Committee of the [[International Xenotransplantation Association]] pointed out in 2003 that one major ethical issue is the societal response to such a procedure.<ref>{{cite journal|author1=Sykes M |author2=D'Apice A |author3=Sandrin M |year= 2003|title= Position Paper of the Ethics Committee of the International Xenotransplantation Association|journal= Xenotransplantation|volume= 10|issue= 3|pages= 194–203|pmid=12694539|doi=10.1034/j.1399-3089.2003.00067.x|s2cid=9145490 }}</ref>

The application of the four [[bioethics]] principles is standardized in the moral conduct of laboratories.<ref>{{cite book|last=Sharp|first=Leslie|title=The Transplant Imaginary Mechanical Hearts, Animal Parts, and Moral Thinking in Highly Experimental Science.|publisher=University of California Press|year=2013|isbn=9780520277960|pages=45}}</ref> The four principles emphasize informed consent, the [[Hippocratic Oath]] to do no harm, using skills to help others, and protecting the right to quality care.<ref>{{cite book|last=Sharp|first=Leslie|title=The Transplant Imaginary Mechanical Hearts, Animal Parts, and Moral Thinking in Highly Experimental Science.|publisher=University of California Press|year=2013|isbn=9780520277960|pages=18}}</ref>

Though xenotransplantation may have future medical benefits, it also has the serious risk of introducing and spreading the infectious diseases, into the human population.<ref name="florencio">{{cite journal|url=https://www.jstor.org/stable/24116896|title=Are Xenotransplantation Safeguards Legally Viable?|last1=Florencio|first1=Patrik S.|last2=Ramanathan|first2=Erik D.|journal=Berkeley Technology Law Journal|year=2001|volume=16|pages=945|jstor=24116896|pmid=15212014|access-date=May 21, 2022}}</ref> Guidelines have been drafted by governments with the purpose of forming the foundation of infectious disease surveillance.<ref name="florencio" /> [[United Kingdom]] guidelines state that patients have to agree to "the periodic provision of bodily samples that would then be archived for epidemiological purposes", "post-mortem analysis in case of death, the storage of samples post-mortem, and the disclosure of this agreement to their family", "refrain from donating blood, tissue or organs", "the use of barrier contraception when engaging in sexual intercourse", "keep both name and current address on register and to notify the relevant health authorities when moving abroad" and "divulge confidential information, including one's status as a xenotransplantation recipient to researchers, all health care professionals from whom one seeks professional services, and close contacts such as current and future sexual partners."<ref name="florencio" /> The patient must abide by these rules throughout their lifetime or until the government determines that there is no need for public health safeguards.<ref name="florencio" />

==== Xenotransplantation guidelines in the United States ====
The [[Food and Drug Administration]] (FDA) has also stated that if a transplantation takes place, the recipient must undergo monitoring for the rest of their lifetime and waive their right to withdraw. The reason for requiring lifelong monitoring is due to the risk of acute infections that may occur. The FDA suggests that a passive screening program should be implemented and should extend for the life of the recipient.<ref>United States Food and Drug Administration. Guidance for Industry: Source Animal, Product, Preclinical, and Clinical Issues Concerning the Use of XTx Products in Humans. Washington, DC: US FDA, 2001</ref>
